body.p:
I were at Mr Evan's three years ago last February when Mr Berry and others came there and had the fight with Mr Evans. I were knowing to. and saw the whole affair. Mr Evans had me summoned and I attended the different courts in 1863 and 4. last September he furnished me with horse and saddle to ride from where I now live, which is on Green River in Edmundson Cty to his house, and then to Glasgow, a distance of twenty three or four miles. On teusday morning, the day we were summoned to attend court. Mr Evans carried with him Mrs McKinney Miss Martha. Evans and myself to Glasgow. Soon after our arrival at Glasgow, Mr Evans came to us and informed us, that he was on the jury, and did not ^know^ when he could go home, and said to us, "that we must do the best we could for ourselves." We came back to Mr Evans that evening and left him at town, he got home a while after dark that night, he started back to town verry early wednesday and came home after dark that night. Thursday morning he started again to town quite early, as usual and returned that night complaining of being quite unwell, on friday morning he said he was verry unwell, we told him he had better not start to town, he said he was compeled to go. he came home that night verry sick with headache and was sick all night, Saturday we were
ready to go to town, and asked Mr Evans if we must go to town. he said he was sick and was in no condition to go to town. he had head ^ache^ all morning on Saturday. keep his bed, about the middle of the day, he got some better and went out to Cave City, came back that evening his head still aching. and was sick that night and next morning. & Mr Evans is in bad health and has been for several years, and has the worst ^spells^ of head-ache I ever saw any person have. I heard Mr Evans speak of the difficulty between himself and Mr Berry several times He always said he was anxious to have the trial over with, he always said if he could have a fair trial, that he had no fears of having anything to pay. Mr Evans was about starting to town with us, on Monday morning after the trial came off on saturday before, when he was informed that the trial was over with, therefore we did not go
Sworn to before me by Mary F. Pulliam this 25th day of April 1865
J F. Dickinson J. P. B. C.
